channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israeli Army Takes Journalists on Controlled Visit to Gaza Hospital
item.description: The military showed Times journalists a shaft that it said was evidence of a Hamas facility under Al-Shifa Hospital, though it was unclear where it led or how deep it was.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed vehicles near the Al-Shifa Hospital on Thursday.

item.title: A Journey Into Northern Gaza: Ruins, Wreckage and Darkness
item.description: Three New York Times journalists traveled with an Israeli military convoy to catch a rare glimpse of conditions inside wartime Gaza. They saw houses flattened like playing cards, and a city utterly disfigured.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers from the Seventh Brigade escorted journalists to see a stone-and concrete-shaft on the grounds of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Israeli and Palestinian Activists Ask Americans to Take Side of Peace
item.description: Sally Abed, a Palestinian citizen of Israel, and Alon-Lee Green, a Jewish Israeli, found polarization in America over the war in Gaza. They also found longing for a new approach.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sally Abed, 32, and Alon-Lee Green, 35, leaders of Standing Together, an organization that works for peace between Israel and Palestine, at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Has Seized Small Dnipro Foothold After Months of Raids
item.description: The Ukrainian military said it had taken a sliver of Russian-controlled land, a move that might offer some hope but was unlikely to lead to a rapid breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the bank of the Dnipro River near Kherson, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: A Dying Anticorruption Crusader Considers His Life’s Own Misdeeds
item.description: Chuwit Kamolvisit has enthralled Thailand for decades with revelations of police and political corruption. But his own compromised past, including time as a “super pimp,” clouds his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A politician known to some as “the godfather of sex,” Chuwit Kamolvisit’s anticorruption efforts have made him a household name in Thailand.

item.title: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni Visits Tolkien Exhibition in Rome
item.description: Italy’s Culture Ministry has opened a curious show dedicated to the life and works of J.R.R. Tolkien — and perhaps a new front in the culture wars. It’s “beautiful.” Just ask the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: The exhibition included a myriad of Middle-earth-themed objects, including a “Lord of the Rings”-themed pinball machine and sculptures of hobbits.

item.title: In Nagorno-Karabakh, Armenia-Azerbaijan Conflict Leaves Raw Wounds
item.description: While the conflict over the breakaway region of Nagorno-Karabakh concluded with an Azerbaijani victory, resentments simmer on both sides, creating fertile ground for new violence.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gulbeniz Magerramova, 67, left, visiting Shusha, Azerbaijan, for the first time since it was recaptured. “I am happy that we returned, but we lost everything that we had here.”

item.title: Seizing Darfur Region, Paramilitary Forces Are Accused of Atrocities
item.description: Seven months into Sudan’s civil war, the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces and its allies are ransacking and capturing the Darfur region. An aid worker said, “People are dying like insects.”
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: A Sudanese woman mourning a relative she said was killed by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces. She had fled from El Geneina in the Darfur region in July, across the border into Chad.

item.title: Younger Israel and Palestinian Activists Dream of a New Peace
item.description: A younger generation of Israeli and Palestinian peacemakers want to be part of the dialogue about the “day after” the war, when Israelis and Palestinians must grapple again with how to live side by side.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: May Pundak, whose father helped negotiate the Oslo Accords, is a human rights lawyer in Israel who hopes to help restart the peace process between Israelis and Palestinians.

item.title: Everton Docked 10 Points, a Premier League Record, in Financial Case
item.description: The penalty adds to the problems of a team operating under a mountain of debt. It vowed to appeal.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Everton’s points deduction dropped the team to 19th place in the 20-team Premier League.

item.title: Ahead of Argentina’s Presidential Election, Milei Is Already Pointing to Fraud
item.description: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian economist, could be elected Argentina’s president on Sunday. If he is not, he has already pointed to fraud.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Javier Milei, a far right presidential candidate, has claimed, without evidence, that stolen and damaged ballots cost him hundreds of thousands of votes in the first round of the general election.

item.title: Pedro Sánchez Secures New Term to Lead a Divided Spain
item.description: The Socialist prime minister won a parliamentary vote only after promising amnesty to Catalan separatists, enraging conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pedro Sánchez, front left, at the Spanish Parliament in Madrid on Thursday. He said his deal with separatists represented “the path of dialogue, understanding and forgiveness.”

item.title: Ukrainians Fleeing Russian Occupation Cross Through Russia Back to Their Own Country
item.description: About 100 Ukrainians a day travel back into Ukraine at an unofficial border crossing, bringing tales of repression and fear about life in Russian-controlled territories.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Tyler Hicks
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: India Rescue Effort Continues for 40 Workers Trapped in a Tunnel
item.description: The Indian authorities are trying a second drilling technique to reach 40 men who are getting by on water and food sent in through a pipe.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Rescue operations at the site of a collapsed tunnel in the mountainous state of Uttarakhand in India.

item.title: Xabi Alonso Isn’t Coming to Save Your Team. Not Yet.
item.description: The patience of Alonso, the Bayer Leverkusen manager, says a lot about him, and just as much about a sport perpetually chasing the next big thing.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Xabi Alonso, top of the Bundesliga but still taking his time.

item.title: Iceland Works to Protect Power Plant as it Awaits a Volcanic Eruption
item.description: As the country prepares for a possible volcanic eruption, it’s working to protect a power plant that serves 30,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A police officer near a crack in the road in Grindavik, Iceland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Celebrity Campaign Shines Spotlight on New Zealand Bird Contest
item.description: An endorsement from the comedian John Oliver led to a spike in votes for the eventual winner, the pūteketeke.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A poster promoting the comedian John Oliver’s campaign for the pūteketeke to be named New Zealand’s Bird of the Century in Wellington, New Zealand.

item.title: Russia Sentences Activist to Penal Colony for Antiwar Notes on Price Tags
item.description: A court sentenced Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko to seven years in a penal colony, in one of the most prominent cases of Russia’s crackdown on wartime dissent.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksandra Y. Skochilenko reacting to the court’s ruling against her in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Israel’s search of a major hospital in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Satellite images of the Al-Shifa hospital complex, compiled using photos and videos released by the Israeli military, statements from health officials in Gaza and images from Maxar Technologies.

item.title: International Court Orders Syria to Stop Torture of Political Opponents
item.description: Human rights experts have estimated that some 14,000 people died from torture or were killed in the prisons run by military intelligence and security forces during Syria’s long civil war.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Syria, which was ordered to stop torturing imprisoned opponents, did not send a representative to the hearing at the International Court of Justice in The Hague.

item.title: Pressure Mounts as Israel Searches Al-Shifa Hospital for Hamas Presence
item.description: The Israeli military said troops had uncovered a Hamas tunnel shaft underneath the Al-Shifa Hospital complex, as well as a vehicle on the hospital grounds packed with weapons.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Al-Shifa Hospital, in northern Gaza, is the enclave’s largest hospital complex.

item.title: Canada Convicts Nathaniel Veltman In Killing Of Muslim Family
item.description: A judge is expected to rule on whether Nathaniel Veltman, 22, also committed terrorism when he rammed his pickup truck into a Muslim family in June 2021.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The funeral for four members of the Afzaal family, who were killed in 2021 after a man, later identified as a white supremacist, ran them over with his pickup truck.

item.title: For Biden, a Subtle Shift in the Power Balance With China’s Xi Jinping
item.description: For the first time in years, a Chinese leader desperately needed a few things from the United States.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: As President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China met in Woodside, Calif., on Wednesday, Mr. Xi stayed away from the aggressive “wolf warrior” tone he had once encouraged.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Continues to Search Al-Shifa
item.description: Plus accusations of atrocities in Darfur.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A satellite image of Al-Shifa Hospital and its surroundings in Gaza on Saturday.

item.title: San Francisco Protesters Demanding Gaza Cease-Fire Shut Down Bay Bridge
item.description: Westbound traffic into San Francisco was blocked, causing enormous traffic jams on highways in the East Bay. At least 50 people were arrested.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:description: Protesters chained themselves to cars to shut down the westbound lanes of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge on Thursday.

item.title: Israel Says Bodies of 2 Hostages Were Recovered Near Al-Shifa Hospital
item.description: Israeli officials say the hospital complex hosts major Hamas facilities, some in underground bunkers, a claim that Hamas and hospital officials reject.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house at Be’eri kibbutz in Israel that was overrun by Hamas armed fighters on Oct. 7.

item.title: Panda Diplomacy Might Not Be Dead Just Yet
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China said his country may keep sending giant pandas to the United States. The National Zoo in Washington sent three of them back to China last week.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China said in a speech on Wednesday night that giant pandas might soon return to zoos in the United States.

item.title: Day After Xi Meeting, Biden Says U.S. Has ‘Real Differences’ With China
item.description: Mr. Biden won applause when he noted that he and Mr. Xi had agreed to resume military-to-military communication to “reduce the risk of miscalculation.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in the gardens at the Filoli Estate in Woodside, Calif., on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza Is Plunged Into a Communications Blackout Amid a Severe Fuel Shortage
item.description: Major Palestinian networks said “all telecom services” in the Gaza Strip were down, leaving most in the enclave cut off from the outside world amid an escalating Israeli operation.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city of Khan Younis in southern Gaza during a power outage earlier this month.

item.title: How International Law Views Israel’s Military Action at Al-Shifa Hospital
item.description: Human rights laws prohibit harming or interfering with a hospital like Gaza’s Al-Shifa, with very narrow exceptions, or using it as a human shield. Attacking one can be a war crime.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The Al-Shifa Hospital compound last week.

item.title: Israel Blocks Palestinian Americans From Entering From West Bank
item.description: The move is an apparent violation of a recent agreement that says citizens from the United States and Israel can travel to the other nation without a visa.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan, Edward Wong and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The West Bank in October. Palestinian-Americans have faced difficulties traveling to the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

item.title: Finland Will Close 4 Border Crossings With Russia to Stem Migrants
item.description: Officials accused Moscow of loosening migration controls. Relations between the countries deteriorated after Finland joined NATO following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Vesa Moilanen/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Nuijamaa border crossing into Finland on Thursday. Finland said Russia had started letting people travel “without the proper documents.”

item.title: Cameron Meets Zelensky on His First Visit to Ukraine as U.K. Secretary
item.description: With much global attention turned to the war in Gaza, President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned that his country cannot afford a “frozen conflict” with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in live fire during a training exercise in Donetsk last month.

item.title: Israel’s Opposition Leader Says Netanyahu ‘Must Go Now’
item.description: Yair Lapid says that he would join a coalition without Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Israeli opposition leader Yair Lapid, center, arriving at a polling station last year. “Israel has lost faith in the prime minister,” he said on Wednesday.

item.title: China’s Xi Jinping Draws Elon Musk, Tim Cook and Other U.S. CEOs to Gala in San Francisco
item.description: Amid frosty U.S.-China relations, Xi Jinping emphasized friendship in an address to executives from Apple, Boeing, Nike and others.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China spoke to a crowd of U.S. business executives at a dinner in San Francisco on Wednesday evening.

item.title: UK Labour Party Suffers Rebellion on Gaza Cease-Fire Vote
item.description: More than a quarter of Labour lawmakers in Parliament backed a motion calling for a cease-fire amid growing concern over casualties in Gaza and rising pressure on European politicians.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters outside Parliament in London on Wednesday, demanding that lawmakers vote for a cease-fire in Gaza.

item.title: In Talks With Biden, Xi Defends China’s Rise, While Seeking to Reassure
item.description: China’s depiction of Xi Jinping’s U.S. visit reflected his sometimes-contradictory priorities: to project both strength and a willingness to engage with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and David Pierson
item.media:description: President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in the gardens at the Filoli Estate in Woodside, Calif., on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperative conference on Wednesday.

item.title: Fire at Coal Firm Office in China Kills at Least 26
item.description: The fire, at a coal company’s offices in the province of Shanxi, also left at least 38 people hospitalized, the state-run news media reported. The cause was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Joy Dong
item.media:description: The fire at the Yongju Coal Industry Joint Building, in Luliang City, Shanxi Province, China, as seen in a screen grab obtained from a social media video.

item.title: Madagascar Votes Amid Violence and Calls for Boycott
item.description: Tensions are high on the island nation off the coast of southeastern Africa, as opposition presidential candidates complain of a rigged election and abuses by security forces.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Opposition supporters run for cover as riot police officers use tear gas in Antananarivo, Madagascar’s capital, on Saturday. Since campaigning began in October, demonstrators and security forces have clashed at political rallies and protests.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Calls for Days-Long Humanitarian Pauses in Gaza
item.description: After weeks of division, the Council adopted a resolution that stopped short of calling for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents displaced from Gaza City were received with water bottles in Khan Younis last week. Many residents of northern Gaza used four-hour long humanitarian pauses to flee the area toward the south of the strip.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Israel’s raid of Gaza’s main hospital.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinian families sought shelter at the Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City earlier this month.

item.title: Biden Says ‘Real’ Palestinian State Must Come After War
item.description: President Biden emphasized that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will not end without a two-state solution.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden at a news conference in California on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: The Biden-Xi Meeting
item.description: Also, what to know about Israel’s raid on Gaza’s largest hospital.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Joe Biden greeting President Xi Jinping in Woodside, Calif. on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Seizes Gaza Hospital That Became Symbol of the War Itself
item.description: A raid of a hospital that Israel asserts is a base for Hamas is shaping up as a watershed moment in a conflict that has put the Mideast on edge.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: Satellite image of Al-Shifa Hospital and surroundings in Gaza City, on Saturday.

item.title: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander Seeks to Nullify His Purchase of Toronto House
item.description: Irate investors looking for a bankrupt “crypto king” were regular visitors to the new Toronto-area home of Shai Gilgeous-Alexander of the Oklahoma City Thunder.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, left, who represents Canada in international basketball competition, was forced out of his Toronto home by threats intended for the former owner.

item.title: Russian Payments to Top Journalist Hubert Seipel Jolts Germany
item.description: The revelation that the broadcaster Hubert Seipel accepted payments from an oligarch is stirring worries in Germany that Russia is using an old playbook to promote its interests.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:description: An Arabic translation of the 2015 biography by Hubert Seipel, “Putin: Inner Views of Power,” on display at the Abu Dhabi International Book Fair last year.

item.title: ‘Absolute Chaos’: Residents Evacuated From Public Housing Tower in England
item.description: The evacuation of a tower block in Bristol, after surveys found structural concerns, drew fresh attention to the construction of Britain’s public housing high-rises and possible safety issues.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/PA Images via Getty Images
item.media:description: Residents of Barton House in Bristol, England, were told to immediately evacuate the building on Tuesday evening after surveys identified possible structural problems.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Appear to Be Near Hostage Deal, Officials Say
item.description: Under the proposed agreement, Hamas would release 50 women and children abducted during the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks for roughly the same number of Palestinian women and children held in Israeli prisons.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Matthew Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas and other Palestinian groups are holding around 240 people hostage in Gaza, according to Israeli officials.

item.title: Antisemitic and Anti-Muslim Hate Speech Surges Across the Internet
item.description: Fueled by the conflict between Israel and Gaza and stoked by extremists, hate speech has spiked on social media platforms such as X, Facebook and Instagram, researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antisemitic and Islamophobic hate speech has soared on social media platforms since the war broke out between Hamas and Israel.

item.title: What I’m Reading: A History Of Forced Population Transfers
item.description: A history of forced population transfers sheds light on present conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Greek refugees in the early 1920s, after the Treaty of Lausanne ended the conflict between Greece and Turkey.

item.title: ‘Woman With the Flower Tattoo’ Is Identified 31 Years After Her Death
item.description: Interpol began an effort this spring to identify 22 women who had been found dead over the years, leading to more than 1,000 tips. Now, one woman has a name.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Ski Trial Is Getting the Musical Treatment
item.description: Is there nothing that can’t be put to song? A small London theater production about the much-covered trial will ask the audience to be jury members.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A jury this year found Gwyneth Paltrow, the actress and Goop founder, not liable in a crash with another skiier in Utah in 2016.

item.title: Palestinian and Israeli Teens Swam in the Same Pool. Then Came Oct. 7.
item.description: The teenagers in the Greater Jerusalem swim club made a point of not focusing on their differences. That changed with the war.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Afif Amireh
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times

item.title: French Judges Issue Warrant for Syria’s President in War Crimes Case
item.description: The warrant relates to the deadly use of chemical weapons and is a major step to hold President Bashar al-Assad accountable for some of the worst atrocities in Syria’s long conflict.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria speaking in Damascus in July.

item.title: Sailors Trade Tips on How to Stop Orca Attacks on Boats
item.description: With a pod of the sea creatures ramming boats in the Strait of Gibraltar, some crews are turning to homegrown solutions. Can playing heavy metal really keep them away?
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Israel says it found weapons at Al-Shifa, as its troops interrogate people there.
item.description: Al-Shifa hospital has become emblematic of Israel’s campaign to wrest control of Gaza from Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City earlier this month.

item.title: Biden-Xi Talks Lead to Little but a Promise to Keep Talking
item.description: Both American and Chinese accounts of the meeting indicated scant progress on the issues that have pushed the two nations to the edge of conflict.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Katie Rogers
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China met at a lush estate in Woodside, Calif., on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘Erase Gaza’: War Unleashes Incendiary Rhetoric in Israel
item.description: Experts say that inflammatory statements by prominent Israelis are normalizing ideas like the killing of civilians and mass deportations.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Strikes in northern Gaza, seen from Sderot, Israel, on Oct. 29.

item.title: Lull in Russian Bombing Brings Sleep to Kyiv Residents
item.description: An unusually long lull in Russian bombing has left people in the Ukrainian capital feeling well-rested, healthier and more productive, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
item.media:description: Last month, air raid sirens sounded six times in Kyiv, the fewest number since the Russian invasion started in February 2022.

item.title: What One Photo Shows About a Gaza Hospital in Chaos
item.description: A single photograph captures the horror of a hospital in Gaza that is running out of everything but patients.
item.dc:creator: Samar Abu Elouf
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: So Thieves Nabbed Your Catalytic Converter. Here’s Where It Ended Up.
item.description: The pollution control devices contain valuable metals, making them a hot commodity for recycling. Some beneficiaries of the thefts look the other way.
item.dc:creator: Walt Bogdanich, Isak Hüllert and Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: The innards of a catalytic converter are coated in some of the rarest, most expensive metals on the planet.
